video.title: Web Scraping with Python - Beautiful Soup Crash Course
video.description:
Learn how to perform web scraping with Python using the Beautiful Soup library.

✏️ Tutorial by JimShapedCoding. Check out his YouTube Channel:
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCU8d7rcShA7MGuDyYH1aWGg

🔗 You can get code snippets here: http://www.jimshapedcoding.com/courses/Python%20Web%20Scraping

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
Local HTML Scraping:
⌨️ (00:00) Basic HTML Structure, HTML Tags Explanation
⌨️ (05:35) Packages Installation
⌨️ (07:23) Scraping Usage, Local files
⌨️ (12:41) Beautiful Soup find & find_all() methods
⌨️ (16:22) Web Browser Inspect tool
⌨️ (18:30) Grab all Prices, Basic Scraping Project

Website Scraping:
⌨️ (24:48) Using the Requests Library to see a Website's HTML  
⌨️ (30:10) Scraping a Production Website, Best practices for pulling info
⌨️ (44:05) Looping through similar soup.find_all() objects

Features addition:
⌨️ (48:26) Prettifying the Jobs paragraph
⌨️ (54:05) Jobs Filtration by owned skills
⌨️ (57:45) Setting up the Project to scrape every 10 minutes
⌨️ (1:01:53) Storing the jobs paragraph in text files

⭐️ Special thanks to our Champion supporters! ⭐️ 
🏆 Loc Do
🏆 Joseph C
🏆 DeezMaster

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Johanna
topLevelComment.text:
This is a great tutorial, thank you for your hard work :} 
I did run into some problems with the requests package though and want to post my solution just in case anyone else encounters those issues. Even though I had installed requests I got an error message that there was no module called requests installed even though it definitely was. This can happen when there is more than one Python distribution installed. One way to deal with this is to create a virtual environment (venv) for Python and install requests in there. There are tutorials on how to do that on Youtube and it really isn't difficult. When using IntelliJ it is especially easy imo. So in case you get an error and are 100% sure that you did install requests, try a venv.

topLevelComment.author: ktsai24
topLevelComment.text:
Newbie questions I had:

1. The program he's using is called PyCharm.
https://www.jetbrains.com/pycharm/

2. The installation process can be done in PyCharm by clicking the Terminal tab at the bottom-left or by opening Command Prompt (in Windows).

3. Installation location - I spent over 2hrs bashing my head because none of the code worked. Still don't really understand, but anyway, make sure the packages are installed in the same location as your python.exe. My packages installed in C:\\User\myname\AppData\Roaming... So in PyCharm go to: 

a) Settings > Project > Python Interpreter.
b) Next to the top address bar click the gear symbol > Add.
c) Click Existing environment > next to address bar click three dots ... > select python.exe in the same installation location.

My python.exe wasn't there so I found it in C: drive and copy/pasted into C:\Users\myname\AppData\Roaming\Python\Python39\Scripts. Then I did steps a-c.

replies.author: JimShapedCoding
replies.text:
Great question, when Python raises an exception, the exception has been raised not from YOUR file, but from it's inner libraries, if you think about it, each built-in function like len,print,type, has it is own code to describe their functionality, and so the len built-in function is probably located at this file called __init__, and it's exception is being raised from this specific line.
You can see the inner resources of built-in functions by selecting the keyword/variable and press ctrl+b on Pycharm (Or F12 if VS Code)

replies.author: Honyopenyoko
replies.text: In many (most) cases web scraping violates the terms of service of the site you’re scraping however there are no real penalties unless you have an account, for example, and they determine you’re doing it, they’ll likely ban your account. It’s not illegal...just borderline unethical in many cases and the video should at least mention that. Note if you use what you scrape for commercial purposes you’re likely going beyond simple TOS violation into IP theft and can be sued. As another responder stated, you should ask for permission and if the site has an api, obviously, use it.

replies.author: Wimpie Vermaak
replies.text: Not illegal as such, but it is best to communicate and request permission. It is frowned upon by a lot of companies.

@Honyopenyoko I am in no way an expert, but I know when a tutorial is just bad and does not even teach you anything close to the theme it aims to teach. Also I said that this is a good video, way better than somebody's else video (not on fcc) that just taught you how to click to an element using selenium. Like, this is python we are talking about, selenium should be the last approach we take if all the other ways fail. Selenium is slow because it has to control a web-browser. When writing code your aim is to make it efficient and fast, by using the requests library in combination with the BeautifulSoup library you can achieve that.
Selenium is only useful for lazy people or edge cases that you need to interact with the webpage.
